content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V, which manage federal property, regulate financial institutions, and oversee mail delivery. The bill also covers general provisions in Title VII, Cuba sanctions in Title I, and funding for the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia in other titles. Additionally, it addresses mandatory retirement accounts and other issues. The FSGG bill funds various government agencies, including the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. It also addresses mandatory retirement accounts and financial regulation issues. The bill has been in its current form since 2007 and is consistent between the House and Senate, except for the funding of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The FSGG bill funds government agencies outside of the appropriations process. The House and Senate bills fund the same agencies, except for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. President Trump's FY2018 budget request included approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies funded through the FSGG bill, with $330 million for the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018, with $253 million in funding for the FSGG independent agencies. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018, with $253 million in funding for the FSGG independent agencies, including $330 million for the CFTC. The total funding for the independent agencies would have been $501 million, which is $2.6 billion below the President's FY2018 request. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018, with $253 million in funding for the FSGG independent agencies, including $330 million for the CFTC.
